content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: IMHO it's good for fastest or shortert:

Using the logarithmus dualis one must check only the decimal numbers.

Python:
print('true'if math.modf(math.log(input())/math.log(2))[0]==0 else'false')

Java:
System.out.println(Math.log(x)/Math.log(2)%1==0?"true":"false");

IMHO it's good for fastest or shortert:

Using the logarithmus dualis one must check only the decimal numbers.

Python:
print('true'if math.modf(math.log(input())/math.log(2))[0]==0 else'false')

Java:
System.out.println(Math.log(x)/Math.log(2)%1==0?"true":"false");
Maybe you should make the result the integer a. This would solve the problem with binary output.

I don't understand this community. People are approving this contribution and saying that you should replace binary output, but when I upload a slightly different contribution without binary output it got only downvotes and rejections:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/7940c7ed80091280de015722efaafe020f49

Anyway here is a simple solution to this puzzle:
print(str(bin(int(input())).count('1')==1).lower())

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: This contribution has binary output

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Text is easy to understand and yet the problem is deeper and more complex making it good for fastest

It has the perfect complexity, as it does take minutes and not seconds to solve because of the good test cases.

Plausible to see powers of two in reverse making it good for reverse although a lot harder than fastest and shortest

The corner cases in the tests make a first to mind brute force solution impossible, forcing more code to optimize for shortest, making it good for shortest as well.

Good job.
According to the guidelines, you must avoid binary-like output (true/false). This makes it too easy to reach 50%. You should rather ask for the power of 2 or -1.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is very easy to understand and can be solved in just the right amount of time.

It is very easy to understand and can be solved in just the right amount of time.
I like this very much.

Please refer to the comments on binary output above. Also please note that puzzles with binary output should not be approved. https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines

Agree to this, printing out the power would make it better, but render your solution useless.

My solution would be for fastest:
n = int(input())
x=2
exp=0
while exp<(n**.5+1):
    if 2**exp==n:
        print(exp)
        exit(0)
    exp+=1
print(-1)
Please refer to the comments on binary output above. The approval should have been withdrawn...
I've solved others with binary output in an official clash :(, and plenty where instead of "true/false" u have to write smth like "RUN/FIGHT" which is pretty much the same - still 2 options.

Maybe it's not well explained and/or test cases are not relevant, especially when it's reverse.

Or they didn't like the part 8=2^3, or decided that searching for the nearest 2 powers of 2 doesn't have a nice trick to or doesn't really acomplish anything.


But feel free to check the provided solution for this  particular problem and learn smth new. You don't need to convert the number to binary or use any loops(e.g. counting symbols) to find out if it's a power of two - unlike "which power of 2", which forces u to use a loop in some sort of way.
I have made it into a separate  task by the name "Powerbyte v2", feel free to support it if you like it.

Please refer to the comments on binary output below. Also please note that puzzles with binary output should not be approved. https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines
I just saw your solution. Pretty clever, nice.
These contributions should not have been accepted. Moreover, there is already a PowerByte v2 which is more compliant. You should definitively remove this one yourself and rename the other PowerByte.

There's an explanation below your initial comment about why it's important for this one to stay the way it is. The v2 i made according to your suggestion, just so you can have the task you found more interesting.
Nevertheless, it is not compliant with CG guidelines and should be removed.
The contribution should have been removed. Now one more non-compliant clash has been approved.
Even worse, there is still a duplicate PowerByte in the contributions. Now, it's all in the hands of the Community Manager.

I started developing this task for educational purposes in "shortest" mode, with the idea that a lot of newcomers probably don't know about binary operations, so they will most probably use a loop to solve this task.

Newcomers will learn something new when clashing(since there will be like 50-100 chars diff), while people who know about binary operations, will have to figure out how exactly to apply it in solving this particular problem.

After that i noticed that writing a loop takes a lot of time compared to writing a simple binary operation, so i thought this task is pretty neat for "fast" as well. Since I already covered corner cases in the tests, that give u the rough idea of what the task is about, I decided to mark it compatible with all 3 modes since it seems to cover all of them anyway.

I admit that changing the task to "which power of two" may be solved similarly (example in javascript):

n =parseInt(readline());
print( !(n&(n-1)) ? n.toString(2).length-1 : -1)

But my guess is that about 95% of the people will either use a loop to solve it or simply count how many 1s are in the number in binary in order to display "-1", which defeats the aforementioned purpose of spreading knowledge about binary operations.
